label: Description
value: Vertical sheet depicing four sketches of steeples or roofs of buildings.  At top right is a square timbered building with irregular roof dormers that do not match.  The dormer over an oval window opening is drawn again in greater detail below, showing the dormer's prominent spike finial.  To the left of this is the drawing of a Gothic tower ending in a tall steeple ornamented with crockets and twin crosses at its apex.  Below this is a drawing of a steeply pitched roof, its gable covered by wooden timbers creating a pointed arch, with a balcony along the lowest row of windows. At bottom left is a tower with three levels ov eaves, and the roof with a large, overhanging dormer on the right side.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on thick cream wove paper tipped into binding with fabric

label: Description
value: Left, two young trees; right, two trees in a meadow shown against wooded hills. Verso, boulders and an evergreen.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite, brush and watercolor on cardboard

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet depicting three sketches of architectural elements of the Château de Fontainebleau.  The upper half of the sheet depicts a tall mansard roof with chimney and a round tower with steep roof and classical dormer to the right.  To the right of this sketch is the letter F, rendered as if made up of masonry segments.  The lower half of the sheet illustrates the clock tower (Tour de l'Horloge) and the pavillon of the Cour de Cheval.  The clock tower is in a very reserved Renaissance style with three stories, each defined by columns at the corners and separated by stringcourses, surmounted by an arcaded cupola and finial.  The pavillion at left is in the French Renaissance style, the two floors dominated by the massive, overscaled mansard roof above.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on cream paperboard tipped into binding with fabric

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet depicting a large half-timber and plaster building at left with an enclosed space at the second story that connects to the adjacent structure at right. Under this enclosed space is an open walkway tow a courtyard beyond.  The room has beams underneath which extend to trusses that support it against the walls of the buildings on the left and right.  The facade of the building on the left has a projecting cornice at the second story which is at the same level of the beams supporting the enclosed space.  This cornice is supported below by decorative wooden brackets with a cyma curve.  An example of one of these brackets is drawn at lower left, shown from the front and a profile that is scaled.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on cream paperboard tipped into binding with fabric

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet illustrating architectural features from the town of Poissy.  At left is a Gothic tower over the crossing of the church of Collegiale Notre-Dame.  It is in an early Gothic style, heavy with masonry.  The tower rises behind the semicircular apse at the lower level, with an octagonal cupola above.  The cupola has double round-arched openings at the carndinal points, and single arches at the ordinal points.  Each opening has louvers.  Above this rises an octagonal roof and finial.  Above right is the picturesque roofline of another building.  It has two chimneys at different heights, a steeply pitched roof in the front, and a tower to the left with an ogee cupola above. Below right is a very small sketch of a window, dormer and chimney from an unidentified building.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on cream paperboard tipped into binding with fabric

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet depicting four sketches of buildings or architectural elements.  The upper half of the sheet has two views of a half-timbered building.  The left drawing shows the building with a masonry first story and half-timber and plaster above.  At right, possibly the same building from the rear. Below is another half-timbered building seen from a three-quarter view.  It has timbering that alternates between straight timbers and those have been carved into an S-shape.  Above is a deep overhang and steep tiled roof.  At right is the steeple of a bell tower, consisting of  a trio of graduated onion domes, and a small finial.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on cream paperboard tipped into binding with fabric

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet illustrating two sketches of architectural elements.  In the center is the clock tower of the Hôtel de Ville (city hall) of the town of Reims, seen from the south.  The octagonal tower rises from the roofline with multiple graduated arcaded cupolas and is topped by a finial with weathervane.  At bottom right is an unusually intricate dormer.  The dormer projects out from the roof ending in a circle. Underneath this small dome is carved and pierced wood, similar to flamboyent Gothic tracery.  The window opening is framed by two scrolling brackets on either side of the window frame.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on cream paperboard tipped into binding with fabric

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet with two sketches of architectural elements.  At left is a short tower rising from a roofline.  The tower has flattened double arches which are louvered, an an ogee cupola faceted steeple with finial and weathervane above.  At right is the corner of a building ending in a gabled roof that has only been partially rendered.  At the corner of the roof is a gutter and turret with a small window, and lower roof with window below it.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on cream paperboard tipped into binding with fabric
Window of the Grande Salle, Château de Blois

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet illustrating part of a wood framed, leaded glass window.  The leading is patterned with rows of faceted rectangles that have been faintly tinted yellowish green to indicate their opacity.  These are separated by small diamond-shaped panes of glass upon which have been painted (likely in yellow- and silver stain) fleurs-de-lys and a small brown symbol. In the center is a roundel of blue glass that frames a porcupine facing left with a crown above.  Around this field is a double border of decorative glass panes.  The outermost border is of yellow guilloche which is intersected by another border of red glass.  Rendered at bottom left of the frame is a flat decorative hinge that has pierced openings in the shape of a heart.  On the right side of the frame is a pierced bar latch to close the window.

label: Physical description
value: Brush and watercolor, graphite on off-white wove paper tipped into binding with fabric
Cresting on Chapel, Château de Blois

label: Description
value: Square sheet that has been cut down to this size.  Illustrated at top center is a section of cresting from the roof of the chapel of the Château de Blois.  The cresting consists of fleurs-de-lys in blue and gold.  The end of the cresting terminates in a blue and gold finial with decorative metal floral elements springing from the top.  To the right of this is another sketch of decorative metalwork from Blois from a finial on the square tower of the château.  The finial has an octagonal base in blue with gold leaves.  Two seahorses are at either side, with a gold flame-like finial at the top.  To the far left is another section of cresting, this time from the roof of the left tower at Château de Blois.  This cresting has sections of metal that create an x-shape, from which small crockets spring.  Above are gold fleurs-de-lys.  This cresting also ends in a finial with an urn with seahorses for handles, a crown above, and a small banner with three fleurs-de-lys with a crown above, and a final fleur-de-lys at the top of the finial.  The roof of both the chapel and this tower are visible, and both have rows of painted yellow fleurs-de-lys.

label: Physical description
value: Brush and watercolor on thick cream wove paper tipped into binding with fabric
Ceiling of Château de Chenonceau, Chenonceaux

label: Description
value: Horizontal sheet tipped vertically into binding.  The sheet illustrates four panels of a woodwork ceiling in the Château de Chenonceau.  Each panel is framed by a golden yellow molding with the face of the woodwork parallel to the floor colored red.  One panel is further decorated with a single golden yellow ribbon of ornament that doubles upon itself at the corners to create fleur-de-lys of loops.  The artist notes that all the panels bore this decoration.  To the right of this is a section or profile of the molding that frames the panels.

label: Physical description
value: Brush and watercolor, graphite on off-white wove paper tipped into binding with fabric
Balcony Railing in Chapel, Château de Chenonceau, Chenonceaux

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet illustrating a balcony, an example of one of its balusters, and profiles of three different moldings.  The balcony consists of three sections: a a balustrade of three balusters alternating with a short column with an engaged half-baluster; a row of alternating carved rectangular and blind vertical panels, and molding course below. There is a small semicircular projection of the balcony out from the center, below which are curved brackets and a small finial. The baluster is created by inverting two gadrooned vases, the upper smaller than the one below.  In the bottom half of the sheet is a scale drawing in graphite only, possibly illustrating short engaged columns with ornament.   This drawing seems to be perpendicular to the one above.

label: Physical description
value: Brush and watercolor, graphite on off-white wove paper tipped into binding with fabric

label: Description
value: A moored barge, shown obliquely from the stern. The Dutch colors are flying.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite, brush and watercolor on cream laid paper

label: Provenance
value: Mrs. William Greenough; 1943: acquired by Museum
Sketches of Balcony Elements in Chapel, Château de Chenonceau

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet illustrating a full scale rendering of the upper section of a balcony balustrade from the chapel at the Château de Chenonceau.  The baluster is drawn at the left side of the sheet, while the molding volume and profile of the handrail supported by the baluster is drawn at right.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on off-white wove paper tipped into binding with fabric
Sketches of Architectural Details, Chenonceaux and Beaulieu

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet illustrating six sketches of buildings or architectural ornaments from Chenonceaux and Beaulieu.  The upper half of the sheet contains four drawings.  From left is a Renaissance style cupola consisting of three arcaded loggias culminating in a cross finial.  The lowest loggia has the tallest arches, between which can be seen a bell. To the right of this is a small sketch of a window and dormer, the dormer having a very high projecting pediment and small flame-like finials on top of it and to the left and right.  To the right of this is a very elaborate dormer, its upper windowed section supported at left and right by two cusped, round-arched buttresses.  Above this is a very small drawing of a cupola and its finial.  The bottom half of the sheet illustrates two complete buildings as opposed to their elements.  At bottom left is a large tower consisting of a group of turrets massed together.  At right is a house seen from the corner, a single turret visible at the left corner, and the peaked roof another seen at right.  A small plan of this structure is drawn below the elevation.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on thick off-white wove paper tipped into binding with fabric
Distant View of Loches from Church at Beaulieu

label: Description
value: Horizontal sheet tipped vertically into binding illustrating a distant town seen from a high point.  Visible are a large round tower at left, two large Romanesque towers with steeples to the right of this, and a few larger, lower rectangular structures with turrets a short distance to the right of the center towers.  To the very far right and closer to the foreground is a belltower with domed cupola.  There is a stand of trees in the foreground, and repeated rows of these trees which create a boundary from the foreground and the town in the distance.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on thick off-white wove paper tipped into binding with fabric

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet illustrating five sketches of two dormers, a belfry, a slate cupola and corner of a house.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on thick cream wove paper tipped into binding with fabric

label: Description
value: Horizontal sheet that has been cut down from a larger one depicting a large masonry farm house with thatched or tiled roof.  It consists of a central building with a projecting tower and turret flanked by two large dormers, and two smaller, single-story wings projecting on either side.  There are chimney stacks at either end of the roof line.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on thick cream wove paper tipped into binding with fabric

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet with five sketches of architectural elements from buildings in Vannes, France.  Clockwise from upper left is the detail of a roof eave showing the practice of extending roof beams far out beyond the wall below and resting the roof rafters on a cross beam that then rests on the floor beams to create a deep shadow.  To the lower right of this is a slate gable with deep overhanging eave and half-timbered decoration below.  At the bottom right corner is a small dormer with a rounded front topped by a ball finial.  To the left of this is the meeting of two corners of a building producing a deep and unusual intersection of the eaves.  Above this is another rendering of this same detail that was sketched below.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on thick off-white wove paper tipped into binding with fabric
Elevation of a House with Balcony, Vannes

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet that has been cut down, illustrating an elevation of a small masonry house with overhanging second story, and single, steeply pitched gable with two window openings below.  Directly above the first story are four curving modiliions that support a balcony above.  The balcony consists of turned balusters.  To the right of this is a scaled drawing of the balcony profile and many inscriptions with the dimensions of each part of the drawing.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on thick off-white wove paper tipped into binding with fabric
Two Copper Gutters, from a 16th-Century Castle, Blois, France

label: Description
value: Left, the brackets of two gutters are shown; upper decorated with a rosette and a leaf, lower decorated with the top part of a lily. Shown in profile with the closed ends of the pipes.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite, brush and watercolor on paper
Sketch of Dormer with Slate Roof, Possibly Vannes, France

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet that has been cut down to make a horizontal rectangle depicting on far left side an elevation of a turret or pitched roof with a ball finial.  Below this is a small dormer that has been covered with slate or terracotta tiles.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on thick off-white wove paper tipped into binding with fabric

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet containing three sketches of buildings and architectural features.  Above right is a detailed drawing of an ornamental design in a slate roof.  The roof tiles are mainly rectangular, however in this section they are diamond-shaped but with an ogee outline and arranged three across to make a diamond pattern.  To the left of this is the side elevation of a masonry structure that has a break in its roof eave that lays on top of small beams laid on top of one another above a small wooden shed-like projection.  Below this is the top of a large, square tower with crocketed spires at each corner and a tracery arcade below its roofline.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on thick off-white wove paper tipped into binding with fabric

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet depicting an elevation of a large building set into a hill that is seen from the corner.  The street level has signage for small shops that are contained within.  This is also the smallest of the three stories, as each subsquent level above hangs over the one below.  The street level seems to be of masonry with many windows, while the upper stories are half-timber and plastered.  At the first and second stories the eaves create a deep overhang and are visibly supported from underneath by large shaped brackets.  The building has a slate or tile roof, and a picturesque roofline with many dormers, gables, and chimneys.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on cream wove paper on secondary paperboard support with painted gold surface tipped into binding with fabric

label: Dimensions
value: 30.9 x 23.6 cm (12 3/16 x 9 5/16 in.), irregular; mount: 31.5 x 24.1 cm (12 3/8 x 9 1/2 in.), irregular

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet illustrating an ecclesiastic structure in the center with an agricultural scene in the foreground.  There appear to be two women wearing long skirts bent over at the waist while working the ground.  One at left is faces forward, while the woman to the right has her back to the viewer.  There is a group of people a distance from this scene standing off to the right behind a fence.  In the background is the large building with a prominent tower in the front. The tower is similar to a cathedra, a large arched opening on two sides with a pediment above.   An ornamented cupola is at the very top.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on green paperboard tipped into binding with fabric

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet depicting a view into an alley where a larger and smaller figure stand at the far end.  Above them is an enclosed, windowed bridge between the façade of the building on the left, and the building on the right.  There are small planted window boxes on the bridge, and it is supported by long timbers from below.  The façade of the building on the right has a slight projection at the second story. The walls of this room rests on floor joists that project out from the building façade.  Verso contains small sketch of a square with a long line projecting from one parallel side.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on thick cream wove paper tipped into binding with fabric
Elevation of Church of the Colégio, Ponta Delgada, Azores, Portugal

label: Description
value: Horizontal sheet tipped vertically into binding illustrating a three-story gray and white stone buliding in the Baroque style.  The elevation consists of a central block divided into three equal parts by engaged columns that extend the height of the first and second stories.  There is a green, flat-arched paneled door in the center flanked by a similar, smaller door on either side.  The small wings along each side of the central block have two small round windows at the first floor level, and then repeat the fenestration of the central block: rectangular windows with small circular windows above.  The second story is almost entirely glass.  Inscriptions are written below the drawing on ruled lines.

label: Physical description
value: Brush and watercolor, graphite on off-white wove paper tipped into binding with fabric

label: Description
value: Horizontal sheet tipped vertically into binding depicting three rows of rectangular patches of watercolor arranged into six columns, inscribed by graphite lines, creating a painter's palette complete with inscriptions of the various colors represented, including: ultramarine, indigo, vermilion, sepia, and Prussian blue.  These same colors are used throughout the watercolors in Warren's sketches.

label: Physical description
value: Brush and watercolor, graphite on textured off-white wove paper tipped into binding with fabric
Sketches of Arcades, verso: Elevation of Cathedral at Amboise

label: Description
value: Horizontal sheet tipped vertically into binding.  It was once folded and has a large crease line down the center of the sheet, dividing it into two halves.  The left side has two registers of sketches; above is a quick sketch of an arcade, while below is a grid of lines.  The right side is also divided into two registers: the upper sketch also illustrates a section of an arcade in elevation quickly sketched, but the various components parts of the arcade are identified by dimensions.  This is repeated for one bay in the bottom register, again with many notations about dimensions as well as inscriptions that appear unrelated to the sketches.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on textured off-white wove paper tipped into binding with fabric
Notes Related to Campanile, Milan, verso: Plan of Tile Floor in Dianne de Poitiers' Bedroom, Chateau de Chaumont

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet that was once folded in half and has a crease across the page which creates two registers occupied by sketches and notations.  The upper half contains a small sketch of engaged columns, a double arch lancet, and a campanile with many inscriptions below and to the right.  The lower half of the sheet contains a sketch of vaulting seen in elevation but drawn upside down on the sheet relative to its orientation in the album.  Sketched across the crease is a small plan, possibly of the campanile in Milan, according to the notation.  All drawings on the sheet contain dimensions. The verso of the sheet contains a drawing in plan on the lower half of an octagonal tile floor in the bedroom of Dianne de Poitiers in the Chateau de Chaumont. This side of the sheet also contains small sections of calculations.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on textured off-white wove paper tipped into binding with fabric
Balustrade Plan and Molding Profiles from Loggia of the Campanile of San Marco, Venice

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet with crease across center creating an upper and lower section of sheet.  The upper section consists of the plan of a balustrade and scaled drawing of a portion of a molding in profile.  Below this is another scaled drawing of a moulding and column cap seen in profile.  Both sketches have many inscriptions with dimensions and distances between each of the various elements in the sketches.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on off-white wove paper tipped into binding with fabric
